Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to push electrons.
How to try and decipher the most disorganized and incomplete lecture notes the world has ever seen.
How to memorize organic syntheses mechanisms.
I learned how to cram things into the days before midterms because this course is not conducive to student learning.
Carbonyl chemistry
organic chemistry 2 reactions and biochemistry crossover topics
Lots of mechanisms of organic chemistry reactions.
General chemical literacy that has helped in other biology courses.
The course helps develop a basic understanding of organic chemistry and mechanisms.

The second semester of orgo was honestly kinda fun. We learned a lot of mechanisms that sometimes felt like memorization, but through that drilling, I feel like I came away from the course with a really good understanding of how and why these types of chemical reactions proceed the way they do. Even though the special topics at the end of the semester were confusing and rushed, I can start to see how what I learned has biological applications. I definitely think I improved my problem solving (frankly puzzle solving) skills.
I grew in my knowledge of processes not only in chemistry, but in biology and physics as well.

I learned various organic chemistry reactions, and I got to practice my understanding of reaction mechanisms and stereochemistry. I also began to see how organic chemistry plays a role in biology and life processes.
Organic Chem skills.
None
Organic chemistry with some biological mechanism thrown (these are emphasized in the exams, especially the final).

In CHEM 221, I learned further applications of basic organic chemistry concepts. Through covering reactions such as Diels-Alder, Claisen and aldol condensation, I learned the importance and the application of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups, as well as relative acidity of chemicals. In addition, I learned the basic concepts of NMR spectrometry and was introduced to how organic chemistry can apply in molecular biology.
Understanding of organic mechanisms from alkynes to carbonyls

As the course title implies, the organic chemistry of life processes. A lot of cool topics actually: the synthesis of neurotransmitters, how your body metabolizes fat, how your liver uses enzymes to detox, peptide synthesis, etc. Even the "textbook" topics were taught in the context of biological processes. I liked this a lot better than the first semester, which felt like we were just learning random reactions for the sake of chemistry.
Organic chem - the basics, continued
Mechanisms. Some cool biological applications, i wish there were more.

I learned about many different reactions and their applications in organic chemistry. I developed my knowledge and skills about how different mechanisms work and further understand the basis behind why they occurred the way they did.
I learned about different organic reactions, how to interpret NMR, and biological applications of organic reactions.

1. An appreciation of the limits of my own memory
2. An understanding of best ways to study and review
3. The subtleties of teaching that reinforce stereotypes and power dynamics in a classroom
4. The impacts of having an unapproachable teacher
5. The necessity of classroom organization and structure
All of the fundamentals of organic chemistry - alkynes, carbonyl reactivity, Diels-Alder, carboxylic acid derivatives, etc.
I learned a lot about many types of reactions and mechanisms, including material related to biochemistry. I built upon the knowledge I learned last semester and learned many new concepts as well.

I learned a lot about organic chemistry and more advanced topics that apply to biological systems. I loved the curriculum of this course, and would recommend a similar course like this to anyone interested.
NMR and tons of orgo mechanisms, with a very nice integration with bio concepts at the end!
How to draw hexagons really well! We learned so many mechanism concerning aromatics.
Very insightful class. Built on the solid base of knowledge formed in the first semester.
I learned both organic chemistry and how to study.
Carbonly chemistry, NMR, resonance, alkynes, reactions, etc
I learned about organic chemistry 2 topics including reactions related to alkynes, aldehydes/ketones, carboxylic acids/derivatives, amino acids/carbohydrates, and other topics.
I learned how to draw hexagons very quickly
Learned organic chemistry concepts and how to apply them.
I think my ability to understand chemical mechanisms and perform chemical synthesises greatly improved.
Memorizing multitudes of organic reactions. Became especially familiar with interactions between electrophiles and nucleophiles.
Carbonyl chemistry and how to think about organic problems.
I learned about organic chemistry and its application to life sciences
Learned how to apply general rules of organic chemistry to specific questions and how to stay on top of a lecture with a relatively heavy amount of material.
I learned a lot of important organic chemistry concepts, such as various reactions and mechanisms and also a little bit of how organic chemistry applies to biology.

lots and lots of mechanisms!
This class left me with a much deeper understanding of the chemistry behind the synthesis and break down of basic organic molecules and gave me a lot of intuition when it comes to reactions surrounding most common functional groups

Learned a ton about organic chemistry! Many of the reactions we learned felt more real; things that organic chemists would actually do in the lab. That being said, theres a much bigger emphasis on biochemistry and how things occur in nature less of the building blocks that you have in semester 1. Examples of this are NMR, Diels-Alder, PLP, peptide formation, sugars, ether synthesis, carbonyl chemistry, aromaticity, amines, drugs, etc. I learned how to apply my baseline understanding of reactions to new problems, and how slightly altering conditions (like acid vs. base or adding peroxides) will result in a different product. Most importantly, I learned the mechanisms behind the reactions. Although that took forever, I am now confident in my understanding of nucleophiles, electrophiles, and what actually happens when you add reagents to a starting compound. This class taught me the importance of organization and that practice makes perfect.

A really good feel for organic chemistry. Disclaimer though I really dont think my experience was the norm. I just really like orgo and I showed up to every lecture, and asked myself and google a lot of questions. The class itself is somewhat inducive of developing actual skills but you can really just memorize stuff/not have to understand or retain much at all
I learned a lot about chemical reaction mechanisms and the general patterns of electron movement. I memorized a huge variety of these various mechanisms.

CHEM 221 was an extension of CHEM 220 and continued to build on the mechanisms that were learned previously; mechanisms were the core of this class and knowing them and like knowing how to recreate them in different circumstances was central to the course at hand
I learned a lot about organic chemistry and also how it applies to real-world situations.
Lots of fundamental knowledge on how the world works at a molecular level. Very cool.
I learned about the chemical synthesis of organic molecules.
Organic chemistry reactions, mechanisms and many applications to human biological systems. Bio and drug applications were much bigger emphasizes than expected.
I learned to apply the basic organic che.istry skills from 220 to understand biological molecules and organic reactions that represent life processes or are used in drug development.
None.
How to draw arrows and fling them around molecules.
I mean it's orgo II, follows the format of a pretty typical second semester organic chemistry class
I learned the mechanisms of nearly 50 organic chemistry reactions. I also learned about NMR, resonance, and aromaticity.
I learned more orgo chem mechanisms and principles that built off of first semester's course material.
Continued to build on the foundation of organic chemistry and reactivity learned in chem 220, specifically focusing on reactivity of functional groups such as alkynes, carbonyls, etc.
Continuation of Orgo I
weekly psets would be helpful
Terrible professor, but the TA's made the test so I guess it was better. There was a discrepancy in what was taught and what was on the test.
I think the course should be more organized in terms of the content, homework questions, and practice exams.

The extra credit on exams given out in class was one of the most frustrating and irritating things I have seen done while here at Yale.  It was arbitrary, done excessively, a poor use of class time, and catered exclusively to a specific style of student, while overlooking all those who were less aggressively outspoken in the class.
In a class graded on a curve, where despite the general positive atmosphere and camaraderie, competition between students does directly play a role in personal results, creating non-equal opportunity chances for extra credit is actively unfair. If extra credit is to be given out, it should be for exceptional achievement by individuals, and it should not be dependent on being located in the  best line of sight for your teacher. While having extra credit available for students is a friendly gesture to the class, it is clear that there was not thought put in to ensuring that it would be distributed through a fair mechanism, such as inclusion as a bonus problem on exams, rather than arbitrary selection by the  professor from the class. 
Perhaps even the unfairness could be overlooked if the distribution of these bonus points were not done in a way that was  a noticeably unproductive use of class time. In a class that was already very heavily example driven, taking additional time to have students go up to the board and slowly draw out a mechanism that often required some additional correction (though rarely at the cost of any bonus points) hardly seemed like a helpful use of class time. Having students going to the board is a valuable piece of active learning that often makes sense in a 13 person section where all students can be drawn in to participate, but is not at all practical in a 200+ person lecture. While I applaud the effort to implement active learning principles, I think there are many other ways in which this could be done that would be more practical and time-efficient (eg. clickers). 
As critical as this has been, I would like to reiterate that  I do appreciate the effort that was  made by the  professor.  Clearly this was meant with good intent as a  harmless way to increase class participation and engage with the students, and the spirit behind it was good. In practice however it was an infuriating practice that reduced fairness, class productivity, and created general frustration, and I would strongly press for its discontinuation or at least major restructuring in future years.
It has literally no strengths. The lecture style is disorganized, the expectations for exams are wholly unclear, and it has no redeeming qualities.
Weakness is that the course was very poorly organized/taught on a day by day basis.

This course needs to be reorganized. The notes presented in class are scattered and hard to follow. Emphasis problems from the textbook could also be better selected similar to how they were in CHEM 220.

Weakness: Jason is a poor lecturer. 

Strength: The Exams were easily compartmentalized which made studying really effective.

weakness = lack of homework and weekly problem sets

strength = relevant lecture tops
The tests were fair, until the last one and the final. The TAs were very good, but the lecture felt like a bunch of random drawings with no concepts, so I could never figure anything new out.
This course is highly disorganized. It could really benefit from clear teaching.

This class is very subtly very bad. Crawford sounds like he's doing a fine job explaining concepts, and if you listen to every 10 minute chunk of his lectures in isolation he does a fine job. The class, and his lectures, suffer from a complete lack of coherent organization. He'll often skip around, come back to previously covered material, give you the name the reaction or class of reactions after having explained the whole mechanism, etc. It's easy to not realize this until studying for the exams. The exams themselves are pretty reasonable given what the material is, it is just needlessly difficult to learn. The material is essentially straight memorization which makes it uninteresting, and Crawford doesn't do much to salvage that. He attempts to incorporate bio stuff into the last few lectures, except often doesn't actually explain what the connection to the previously covered material which makes it difficult to contextualize and makes the only potentially interesting part of the class mostly just frustrating. The exams are the only forms of feedback other than PSETs written by the TAs, who apparently aren't told what topics are going to be tested on because the PSETs don't correlate even remotely to the exam questions. The book problems are also at best tangentially related, and despite his description of his own personal selection of book problems to be used for practice as "emphasis problems" they emphasize concepts that he either never covers in lecture, aren't going to be tested on, or both.

This lectures for this class were disorganized and it was unclear what was expected of us to know until about a week before an exam. Oftentimes, the professor would digress into different reactions and topics that we did not quite understand, and it was still unclear whether we were expected to know these things or not. The notes on the chalkboard were extremely messy and did not seem to follow any coherent flow of information. The notes posted on Canvas (which are ostensibly better versions of the information given in class) were also minimally helpful, as they did not follow any sectioning of content and the mechanisms did not follow any coherent flow.
Strengths are relevant course material and low workload. Weakness is lectures can be hard to follow and canvas documents are not helpful.

I thought the course had a fairly good overview of organic chemistry and the tests were very fair. I'm not if I truly understood the background behind all the mechanisms and it often felt like I was simply memorizing material. The materials uploaded on Canvas were super helpful, especially the extra practice questions.

Fascinating material, but disorganized. Crawford is obviously very intelligent and passionate, but the lack of structure for his notes really threw off my studying this whole semester. Sometimes he would go to another topic with saying anything, or writing a new heading, and it would be confusing.

I think that Prof. Crawford did a good job of keeping the class engaged during lecture by having students solve problems on the board and encouraging group work, but I think he could've done a better job of making sure that everyone was following. If the one volunteer who went up to the board got the problem right, he assumed that everyone understood and plowed ahead, which was frustrating at times. On that note, the class could've made some of the connections between the topics clearer--they were very difficult to learn in lecture because they were all presented as somewhat discrete, but when I went back and studied them myself, it became a lot easier because there were only a few guiding principles that applied a lot of the time. Section was also a huge strength--it was hugely important for me to go and just go through the topics we had learned in the past week more slowly and in a smaller group setting.
Students would likely benefit from quizzes. Its a good way of ensuring that students keep up with the material.

I felt that the ties to life processes were interesting during this course but didn't really appear until the last few weeks. Additionally, the last few weeks felt quite rushed, and it seemed that we were speeding through a lot of reactions. I also felt that the content during lecture could sometimes be disorganized, which could be confusing in lecture but also in going back and trying to understand what was covered and what we need to know. Lastly, I felt that the grading scheme was perhaps a little harsh, as the final counted for 50% of the grade. This made it seem like an entire semester's worth of work could be overshot by one bad test.
There was no mandatory homework or quizzes so it was hard to gauge how you would do on exams. Exams also make up a large percent of your grade so it was hard to have a buffer for your grade.

This course was very poorly taught and incredibly unorganized. The entire course grade is determined by three exams, with the final worth 50% of the entire course grade. Pedagogically, this encourages cramming and is detrimental to overall educational goals of retaining material.  I do not feel that I gained any worthwhile organic chemistry intuition or knowledge beyond being able to regurgitate mechanisms and information for exams and subsequently forget the material. Professor Crawford is often condescending, made a number of uncalled for analogies throughout the semester (the most offensive of which was comparing pregnancy to cancer), and puts a biochemical twist on the curriculum that deviates from the core of organic chemistry II, introducing mechanisms that even the TAs were unfamiliar with. This course would be improved under different supervision and by teaching a curriculum which either better aligns with the available text or by providing more thorough, clear and organized course notes and supplemental practice materials.

Prof. Crawford really tries to minimize rote memorization and emphasizes basic concepts. He is very skilled at providing many examples that can help us really understand the basic concepts and how to apply them, rather than just memorizing reactions. However, I believe that the grading breakdown is not conducive to this approach. The fact that 100 percent of the grade comes from exams is a little anxiety-inducing, and it naturally leads to students cramming moments before exams. (I know that the ideal student would review concepts on a regular basis, but most of us are not like that.) To mitigate this, I think a lot of people can benefit if CHEM 221 were to institute the four 10-minute in-class quizzes, just like CHEM 220.

Somewhat disorganized, and the grade is concentrated solely in exams, but it was very study-able. Workload was about the same as other Yale courses because there were no psets but studying for 3 midterms and the final was super time consuming

Strengths: course content. The content was a lot more relevant for biology and medicine and so I felt more engaged with the content than I did in orgo 1.

Weaknesses: Lack of resources. Unlike the first semester, you don't get as many practice tests and you don't get the quizzes to prepare for exams. This puts all of the weight on the 2 midterms you keep and the final, which was a whopping 50% of your whole grade.

weakness: boring lecture course, could be helped by some more engaging learning methods, rather than three exams.
strengths: well organized, well explained
There are no problem sets that are graded, so staying on top of weekly work is really up to students.

The course lacked a clear sense of organization and a unifying direction for the reactions that we were learning. I wish one subject could flow logically into the next so that it was easier to understand within the context of what we were learning.

A strength is that exam topics were fair to what we learned. It can improved with clearer assignments of the text and homework problems (there were sometimes disconnect between what was assigned and what was covered in class).

Strengths: expectations for exam material was very clear. Lectures were well taught.

Weaknesses: sometimes not enough supporting material for exam topics. So required a bit of outside research.

Weakness: 
1. Lack of lecture structure and organization (objectives at the beginning of class would be helpful, as would section headings each time a new topic was approached) 
2. Unclear class notes posted on Canvas
3. Inaccessibility of office hours (due to timing and location)
4. Extra problems were not clearly assigned, making it difficult to know what to practice
5. Failure to integrate information across chapters clearly (e.g. how is this lecture related to the last lecture or the one 5 weeks ago)
6. More practice midterms/finals were needed
7. Lack of ability to gauge the class. I really appreciated that professor Crawford asked the class a lot of questions to gauge our understanding HOWEVER he was unable to properly utilize this information. For example, Professor Crawford would often ask a question and get a wide arrange of responses, few of which were the correct answer. He would then pick out the two people who said the correct answer, and say "I heard the correct answer, you guys clearly understand" instead of reviewing that topic, which was clearly needed. 
8. HORRENDOUS PARTICIPATION INCENTIVE! Professor Crawford asks students to come to the board to demonstrate their knowledge, often rewarding them +2 bonus points. In theory this sounds great, but it is necessarily exclusive. Only students who feel like they have the least to lose were willing to go up. As a result, the majority of the students who went to the board were cis-gendered, white males. Of course there were exceptions, but it was evident that women and people of color were not going up to the board. Power-dynamics had a lot to do with this, but I doubt Professor Crawford ever noticed this, as he never did anything to address it or find ways to get OTHER students to participate. I understand that participation is a crucial part of creating a rewarding lecture experience for both the professor and their students, but it must be INCLUSIVE. Moreover, the bonus points were not helpful. They mainly helped those who needed the least amount of help.
9.  Professor was condescending. Several times I asked a question and the response was "You don't know this?" I was shocked, especially because several other students had the same question as me.

I really enjoyed the material covered in this class, but I think the class's structure could be improved. The lack of any psets or graded assignments make it very hard to stay accountable and keep up with the material. Even if assignments were worth a very small percentage of the grade, it would be helpful to stay on top of work.

The strengths of this course are that the topics covered are very interesting. it was a lot of fun to learn the material for this class, and I felt like I learned a lot about organic chemistry mechanisms and general chemistry knowledge. The weakness is that it was a little disorganized. Crawford is not the most organized professor, and his notes are very confusing. The tests were not written super clearly, which was another issue. The review sessions for the second and third midterm held by the TAs was not helpful at all and also was disorganized. These should/could be improved.
It was good as it could be given it was an orgo course, but I wish there had been a bit more review of Semester 1 concepts and throughout the semester closer to midterms.

Strength: discussion section
Weakness; everything; professor's lectures are disorganized and in general wish the class had more structure/ followed the text book more clearly
The class follows the textbook very closely. Lectures were very clear and well taught.

The course is interesting, but not very well taught. The lectures are nowhere as in depth as the exams, and the textbooks do not cover the material as thoroughly as the exams do either. The TAs did not seem very familiar with the material and could not help much either.

Strengths: professor provides list of exam topics and the midterms are pretty fair based on these topics 
Weaknesses: professors notes arent as organized as Ellmans so piecing together the info is a struggle but if you manage to figure it out its not too hard

A strength of this course is that it is well-paced and covers important reactions (e.g. ones that we would need to know for the MCAT). Another strength is that the TA's are all very knowledgeable and good at re-covering material that was confusing in lecture. A weakness of the course is that Prof. Crawford sometimes goes over things very quickly in class, and we don't have a chance to ask questions. Additionally, he holds office hours when most students can't attend, so it's difficult to get personalized help from him. The course could be improved by giving students a chance to answer questions in class, and also by Prof. Crawford holding more office hours.
One strength was that Professor Crawford would help us hone study topics prior to exams. One weakness is that it was often unclear which parts of the textbook we should read / understand.

Professor Crawford was the weakness. He was not organized with his lectures and did not deliver the material in a way that was easily receivable by students. The TAs were the strength of this course. Without them, I would have completely failed the course.

If Professor Crawford simply put titles for each portion of his notes so there was a general phrase or word to describe what the notes represented, that would make the class material immensely more digestible. The class was very good at allowing for questions so that concepts could be better understood.

This course would be better is it was three days a week (like most large chemistry lectures) instead of 2 because the material is so dense. Overall, lectures were pretty good could but could use some more organization and linearity. The homeworks posted online (which we didn't have to turn in) were very helpful in learning the course material but it would be better if the answer keys contained more detail. 
The Teaching Fellows need to go to the lectures; too often during sections and review sessions led by the TFs, it was obvious that they hadn't gone to lecture. They didn't know the level of detail that had been gone into during lecture and sometimes thought we knew a lot more than we actually did.

Strengths- fair grading system with tests, great support system with TFs, professor was transparent with what topics/concepts would be on the test
Weaknesses- unfair point distribution on tests, hard to follow lectures due to disorganization of presentation of topics
Egregious errors in grading should be looked at harder. There should be more supervision over TAs.
I think there was a lot of bio chem in the course, which is fine, but I think that it could be a little bit more chem focused.
Very interesting base content; but unfortunately due to the sheer volume of reactions needed to be memorized, sometimes the interesting part disappears in favor of rote memorization.
The discussion sections really help students, and the professor posts his lecture notes, though they are not always easy to follow.

The course was pretty good! I didn't love the sections we had to use powerpoint for, and I think it could incorporate examples of real world applications even more. I loved when we discussed how drugs work and are metabolized by the body. More focus on biological applications is better!

One very frustrating thing about this course was that in practice and exam answer keys, even if the question had asked for a mechanism, the mechanism wasnt included in the key. This reflects an overall emphasis on product vs. mechanism, which is inhibitory to learning (if only the products are give, we cant learn where exactly we went wrong).

The strengths of this course are that we are given practice problems that resemble the tests and midterms. The weakness of this course is that it is quite disorganized and also the entire grade for the class depends on three tests, with the final worth 50% of our grade.
great class! enjoyed its organization and how clear what we needed to know was laid out in front of us

Strengths:
1. Section was really helpful
2. The problem sets were focused and helpful
3. The three midterms were fair
4. Releasing focus topics was helpful

Weaknesses:
1. Lecture is rather disorganized. I can follow along during class, but then I look back at my notes at the end of class and I dont really remember any of it. Looking at the notes online were also disorganized, although the folders on canvas themselves were organized.
2. Letting students go up to the board for extra points wasted a lot of time in lecture, and so many people wanted to go up to the board for extra credit, that there was no way to give everyone an equal chance
3. The final was not fair it had lots of tricks and no adequate study tools were provided. I was learning the material on the final as I was takin the final. so maybe that should have been introduced during class
4. More practice midterms would be nice

The FREAKING POINTS FOR ANSWERING QUESTIONS DURING CLASS IS LITERALLY RIDICULOUS AND BLOWS MY MIND EVERY TIME I THINK ABOUT IT AREGHHHH.

It does not help. It only harms.

It is almost exclusively people who are really sure about what theyre doing who are brave enough to go up to the board in front of the whole class and answer questions. These people already probably do well on exams and dont need this. 

Out of 20 or so people who answered questions fully FIFTEEN WERE CIS STRAIGHT WHITE MEN. Being brought up in an environment where everything you said was ok even when it was wrong does not mean you deserve two points (often Crawford gives you points even if your answer is wrong.)

In short this policy rewards cockiness and is utterly discriminatory and MUST be removed.

The exams were extremely fair with the practice tests being a great example of questions. Additionally, only content covered in lecture would appear on tests and not random examples from the books. I wish there were more assignments to help with the grading and keep a student responsible for the material.

A strength is the material is such that is is able to be taught in a clear way with connections between units. A weakness is that it was not taught in this way and there is a large amount of material.
Unirganized notes

I would have to say the weakness of the course would have to be how it taught. The first semester of organic chemistry with Ellman proved that although the material is difficult, it can be taught in a way that makes learning the material manageable and doable. The material in this class isnt harder, but the way the class is organized makes it so much harder.

Prof. Crawford was a pretty okay professor but it was helpful when he gave out study topics before each of the exams, and in general, his mechanisms were pretty clear, but sometimes things got a bit hairy and all over the place which made it hard to pinpoint the study topics
The class was very organized.
Weakness: the lectures were somewhat disorganized and it was hard to figure out what information you were responsible for knowing.
I think it should be at a different time -- 9AM on science hill was hard for lots of kids.

Strength: Prof Crawford sometimes stops lecture so the whole class works on example questions together. I think those were very helpful in enforcing what we learned.

Weakness: The last half of the course seemed really rushed, and it was difficult understanding the big picture of each mechanism.

This course is poorly taught in that the notes are chaotic, and it is not at all clear what will be the exams. There were no assessments other than the exams, and that is not conducive to learning. There should be weekly psets (graded for completion perhaps) or at least biweekly quizzes. The exams do not reflect real learning in the course.

The course was taught out of order. Notes in class were not very clear and notes posted to Canvas were messy and missing details. Exams were fair and tested our knowledge well. I would appreciate if we had weekly psets to keep students focused on material covered in class. It was easy to focus on other classes and fall behind in this class until exams came up and students were forced to cram. Parts could include more complicated organic synthesis questions relating to chemical biology and life processes, and drug development that students can work on together in groups and learn more and be more excited about the material from such problems.

There are no strengths to this course, except maybe two TAs. Theres no organization, no resources, and the teaching is disorganized and follows no set curriculum. A syllabus with information on what we should be learning would be nice.

Teach the material coherently! There is so much interesting stuff to learn, so why not teach it in a way that makes sense? Label concepts instead of drawing random mechanisms and whispering their name at the end. Have compassion for students who don't get things the first time around and require further explanation. This course really needs some work. Learn from Orgo I for starters.
The assessments for the course are pretty fair, there's usually a few curveballs but you have the opportunity to succeed with one drop on the three midterms

This class was very poorly organized and it was totally unclear what was expected of students for exams. We were even given contradictory answers from TAs when we asked them what material would be on exams. The lectures did not have titles, and they were hard to follow. They often made simple concepts seem impossibly confusing.
very disorganized and not designed well to facilitate learning
The course covers a lot of material and though it is informative, at times, it became a bit overwhelming trying to keep up with material for exams.

Strengths: great teaching fellows - section was by far the most useful aspect of this course. The book is also fabulous and very effective at both teaching the reactions and explaining the cause of the observed reactivity. The worksheets and list of book problems to focus on were also extremely helpful.

Weaknesses: First and foremost, the policy of extra credit in this class was immoral and discriminatory, as it failed to offer equal opportunities for extra credit to all students. By doing so, it placed students in a position in which they had to choose between sacrificing grades or sacrificing academic integrity. In addition, Dr. Crawford often presented reactions in lecture without fully explaining what they were or how they related to the material we were studying (usually biochemical reactions that occur in nature), and they were often not in the book and thus hard to study. In general, lectures were structured in a way that did not facilitate learning - the best way learn the material was usually reading the textbook.

Suggestion for improvement: change the extra credit policy to one which offers equal opportunity to all students. Additionally, consider changing the format to two sections and one lecture per week.
The professor was not very engaging and did not organize the notes well or give textbook pages that followed the course material.
Yes, very helpful for upper level biochem and bio classes
Not unless you have to. Take it off sequence.
I would not recommend this course unless it was taught by another professor.
Only if you are masochistic or pre-med or a chem major. Otherwise stay away.
Not really, unless you want to memorize a lot of stuff.
Necessary for pre-med.
I wouldn't recommend this course to anyone not in the majors that require it. The class isn't entirely bad, and I felt like I would've enjoyed it more with another professor.
Sure.
Needed for the major
This course was actually so hard, but probably because I never did the psets / really thought about anything while studying, rather than just reading sometimes.

This class is very subtly very bad. Crawford sounds like he's doing a fine job explaining concepts, and if you listen to every 10 minute chunk of his lectures in isolation he does a fine job. The class, and his lectures, suffer from a complete lack of coherent organization. He'll often skip around, come back to previously covered material, give you the name the reaction or class of reactions after having explained the whole mechanism, etc. It's easy to not realize this until studying for the exams. The exams themselves are pretty reasonable given what the material is, it is just needlessly difficult to learn. The material is essentially straight memorization which makes it uninteresting, and Crawford doesn't do much to salvage that. He attempts to incorporate bio stuff into the last few lectures, except often doesn't actually explain what the connection to the previously covered material which makes it difficult to contextualize and makes the only potentially interesting part of the class mostly just frustrating. The exams are the only forms of feedback other than PSETs written by the TAs, who apparently aren't told what topics are going to be tested on because the PSETs don't correlate even remotely to the exam questions. The book problems are also at best tangentially related, and despite his description of his own personal selection of book problems to be used for practice as "emphasis problems" they emphasize concepts that he either never covers in lecture, aren't going to be tested on, or both.
Yes. It's really not as bad as many of the evaluations say.
The course is required for many people and I think it's a fair class that teaches the material fairly well.

You're probably taking this course because you need to for pre-med or a chemistry major or something of the sort, so it's not so much a recommendation for whether to take the course so much as a recommendation to have a good attitude and to put the work in. I think this class was super satisfying and even fun at times, and the times that were hugely overwhelming--the kind of times that give orgo its bad rep--happened because I fell behind or wasn't engaging with the course.
really unnecessary if you are pre-med. very biochem focused. not taught super coherently. only take it if you have to.
Yes, I would. It is an interesting course, and necessary to attend medical school.

I would only recommend this course to someone who is either really interested in the content or has to take it. For the content covered and the work that goes into understanding and using the reactions, someone would have to want to get a lot out of it.
If you need it.
Unfortunately, if you're taking Orgo II its likely a requirement. Hopefully you'll have the opportunity to take it with someone other than Professor Crawford.

Although CHEM 221 is much more difficult compared to CHEM 220, if you pay attention to the bigger picture, you will learn a lot from this course. You have to be good at not getting distracted by individual reactions, but instead at focusing on overarching themes/concepts. All of your grade comes from exams (although you can drop one midterm), and the exams are really difficult. It is really easy to slip into a cycle of not reviewing your notes for weeks, and then try to cram the night before exams. Dont do that! That will create so much stress. Start reviewing slowly, 15 minutes a day. There is no homework or quiz in this course, so all the studying is up to you. Whether this course is enlightening or frustrating will partially depend on your studying habits. With that said, CHEM 221 is not as easy coasting as CHEM 220, but if you took CHEM 220, why not take CHEM 221 also?

If you're reading these reviews or considering taking the class, you probably don't get a choice and so I think this question is irrelevant. What I will say about the course is that although it is much more interesting and relevant to medicine than the first semester, it is much harder. The instructor is not as good, the questions are more challenging (less memorization based), and the grade is 50% 2 midterms and 50% final which can be a little bit rough. On the flip side, it is the lowest workload course I have ever taken.
orgo is fun, but maybe not worth knowing unless absolutely necessary
Yeah take it for pre-med even if you dont have to - way more intellectually stimulating than Orgo 1
Likely you are taking it to fulfill a requirement, be prepared to attend the discussion section to clarify any concepts in lecture.
Yes, if you are interested in organic reactions.
Yes. Very well taught and much easier than general chemistry. The material was far and straight forward.

No. Do not take this course if you do not have to. 

The professor was dismissive and not engaging.
Only if necessary.

I was not required to take the class because I am an MCDB major but not premed, yet I would recommend this class to anyone considering it. I think this information may be helpful in many future courses and endeavors. The information learned was surprisingly fun! It definitely isn't easy and it is hard to stay accountable, but it is definitely worth taking!

Yes, I would recommend taking this course to students who are considering Orgo 2. For most people, you have to take this course. Study hard for the exams because they are not easy. Overall, the content of the class is extremely interesting, so I would definitely recommend taking the class if you are genuinely interested in the material. The final is cumulative, so study for a LONG time for that test, as it will cover a lot of things, and the final was extremely difficult.
I mean if you have to! I love organic chemistry but the competitive setting of a class full of pre-meds and the hard exams make it difficult to enjoy so purely.
No! Absolutely not! If you're pre-med you're better off not taking this class and applying to schools that don't require 2nd semester orgo!

If you are a chemistry major, pre-med, or someone who has to take this class as a requirement, don't be scared to take it. The class is challenging but rewarding and well-taught. If you are someone who isn't required to take it, don't take it unless you are really interested. The work is worth it if you are interested in the subject.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is needed for his or her major.
Yes, if youre premed or a bio major this is important

If students are taking this class they probably have to, but I do think that course has been improved a great deal from previous years. Organization of the class is better, but I think there is still room for improvement. For example, I think TA's could be more standardized in what they cover in section, and Prof. Crawford could be a bit more organized during lecture.
Yes, this course furthered my organic chemistry knowledge and made me much more comfortable with the subject.
Don't take this unless you have to.
I would if you would like to learn organic chemistry. Would help greatly to take CHEM 220 first. I learned a lot of chemistry.

I would recommend this course. Organic chemistry is a beautiful topic and this course is very relevant to many parts of our lives--medicine, food, our bodies. This class is very interesting and explains many of the details that are taken for granted in lower level biology courses (peptide bonds, DNA, etc.).
Only if you need to
I would only take this class is you absolutely have to. It's not anything like Organic Chemistry I. It is much less organized and you'll simply learn less
Yes, Crawford tells you exactly what you need to know for the tests.
Most students will take because they have to
Probably not worth taking if you don't have to, but is pretty cool to know how some processes work on a molecular level.
Most people take this class because they are required to. However, it is not very engaging and is poorly taught. Would recommend taking off sequence.
I would not recommend this course unless it is a requirement. This class requires a lot of work and effort into learning all the material.

This class is about how much work you put into it. Crawford does a good job of giving students the resources to do well. Notes are posted online and he tells you what topics to study for exams. Its all on the student, how much work you put into it.
its a prereq, not too bad! give yourself enough time to learn the material

This semester they definitely dont spoon-feed you like in Ellmans class, but if youre disciplined and go to lecture and section, youll do fine. I think its really important to keep going with orgo, even though its not technically a med school requirement to take the second semester. If you really struggled first semester, then dont take this class because its definitely a level up. However, if you more or less enjoyed first semester, I would definitely encourage you to stick with orgo II and learn more about how organic chemistry is actually useful in science and medicine.

Ummmm it is a learning experience. I learned a lot. It wasnt always pleasant, though some days it kinda was. But if you dont have a strong affinity for the subject itself/are required to take it, this class isnt particularly worth taking.
I would not recommend this course because the professor isnt good. The material is pretty interesting however so maybe take in the off cycle.
Final is half the grade and midterms are the other half. Study on your own or go to your TA
If you are taking this course, most likely you have to, so dont really have a choice.

If you need to take it for your major or something, you should and you will get through it, and it will be fine but if you don't need to, then there are most likely some other cooler chemistry courses; this was a pretty standard lecture course
I would recommend this course for a student who needs to take organic chemistry.
Yes, especially if you need to take it
This course was definitely more difficult than first semester orgo, but it is do-able.
No, sorry you have to take it.
If a student us required to take this class they should. Otherwise I would not strongly recommend it.
No.
Nope. Don't take this class unless you have to. Crawford lacks the teaching/organization skills to effectively communicate his knowledge to students.
You'll need it for a lot of science majors and for premed, but it's not a big bullet to bite.

I would not recommend this course to another student. I think organic chemistry is very cool, and I enjoyed the content of the class. But I found the poor teaching incredibly frustrating and I ended up learning more on my own. If a student wanted to learn the material, instead of taking this class, I would tell them to go online and watch Khan Academy videos. This was how I learned (and I did learn a lot and was able to get excited about the material) but going to class was truly less useful.
if it's required
Yes but only if you are truly interested in the topic or need it. This course requires a lot of study time and is a huge commitment.

Only take this course if you are genuinely interested in organic chemistry. The material was fascinating and well-presented in the book, but overall the lecture was not well taught, so be prepared to more or less teach yourself (with help from the wonderful TA's).

If youre like me, you are taking Orgo for your major, or maybe even for medical school. If youre taking this class for fun I dont know what youre thinking. Like seriously, if you think that organic chemistry II is a good time and youre not a chemistry major, you should definitely be a chemistry major and drop whatever your current major is. Organic Chemistry I is fine, and even sort of interesting at times. Organic Chemistry II is a bunch of random memorization that Ive already forgotten, less than 2 weeks after taking the exam. It is a grueling course, exams are hard, the final is hard, and it takes a lot of time to memorize everything. Proceed at your own risk, but dont say I didnt warn you.
if you need orgo II, take it.
